links.title: Wine dark sea (Homer) - Wikipedia
links.description: The wine-dark sea is a traditional English translation of οἶνοψ πόντος (oinops pontos), an epithet in Homer of uncertain meaning. A literal translation is "wine-face sea". The only other use of oinops in the works of Homer is for oxen, where it seems to describe a reddish color, which has given rise to various speculations about what it could mean about either the state of Aegean Sea during antiquity or the colour perception of Ancient Greeks.

links.title: Color term - Wikipedia
links.description: A color term (or color name) is a word or phrase that refers to a specific color. The color term may refer to human perception of that color (which is affected by visual context) which is usually defined according to the Munsell color system, or to an underlying physical property (such as a specific wavelength of visible light). There are also numerical systems of color specification, referred to as color spaces.

links.title: Curbstone broker - Wikipedia
links.description: The phrase curbstone broker or curb-stone broker refers to a broker who conducts trading on the literal curbs of a financial district. Such brokers were prevalent in the 1800s and early 1900s, and the most famous curb market existed on Broad Street in the financial district of Manhattan. links.title: ARP spoofing - Wikipedia
links.description: In computer networking, ARP spoofing, ARP cache poisoning, or ARP poison routing, is a technique by which an attacker sends (spoofed) Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) messages onto a local area network. Generally, the aim is to associate the attacker's MAC address with the IP address of another host, such as the default gateway, causing any traffic meant for that IP address to be sent to the attacker instead.

links.description: Augmented Graph Grammars (AGGs) are a robust rule formalism for graphs that allow for complex node and arc types, optional substructures, and complex rule expressions. Rather than using a fixed alphabet of graph components they are defined by a complex ontology that allows for subsidiary types such as textual fields, access functions, and directional information.  They can also be used to evaluate negated elements as well as quantified expression...

links.title: Hyperinflation in Venezuela - Wikipedia
links.description: Hyperinflation in Venezuela  is a period of currency instability in Venezuela that began in November 2016 during the ongoing socioeconomic and political crisis in that country.[1] The country has been experiencing a long period of continuous and uninterrupted inflation since February 1983 with double-digit annual inflation rates; from 2006 to 2012 the government of Hugo Chávez reported decreasing inflation rates during the entire period. links.title: Bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate - Wikipedia
links.description: Bis(2-ethylhexyl) phthalate (di-2-ethylhexyl phthalate, diethylhexyl phthalate,  DEHP; dioctyl phthalate, DOP) is an organic compound with the formula C6H4(CO2C8H17)2. DEHP is the most common member of the class of phthalates, which are used as plasticizers.  It is the diester of phthalic acid and the branched-chain 2-ethylhexanol. This colorless viscous liquid is soluble in oil, but not in water.

links.title: ATSDR - Toxic Substances - Di(2-ethylhexyl)phthalate (DEHP)
links.description:
Di(2-ethylhexyl) phthlate (DEHP) is a manufactured chemical that is commonly added to plastics to make them flexible. DEHP is a colorless liquid with almost no odor. 

DEHP is present in plastic products such as wall coverings, tablecloths, floor tiles, furniture upholstery, shower curtains, garden hoses, swimming pool liners, rainwear, baby pants, dolls, some toys, shoes, automobile upholstery and tops, packaging film and sheets, sheathing for...

links.title: The Control of Nature - Wikipedia
links.description: The Control of Nature is a 1989 book by John McPhee that chronicles three attempts (with varying success) to control natural processes. It is divided into three long essays, "Atchafalaya", "Cooling the Lava", and "Los Angeles Against the Mountains".  The Army Corps of Engineers prevents the Mississippi River from changing course, but has had less success in controlling flooding along the river. The residents of Heimaey, Iceland saved their harbor...

links.title: Atchafalaya River - Wikipedia
links.description: The Atchafalaya River /əˌtʃæf.əˈlaɪ.ə/[1] is a 137-mile-long (220 km)[2] distributary of the Mississippi River and Red River in south central Louisiana in the United States. It flows south, just west of the Mississippi River,[3] and is the fifth largest river in North America, by discharge.[4] The name "Atchafalaya" comes from Choctaw for "long river", from hachcha, "river", and falaya, "long".[5]
